bundle, and the bracket #(start)# #(m!lsqbrsqb1x2,-,w,-)# #(m!lsqbrsqb1x2,-,w)# #(-,-,e,w)# #(-,-,e)# #(-,!0,we)# #(-,!0)# #{-,e,w}# #{-,e}# #(end)# is alternating, i.e. it vanishes on #(start)# #(v!x,!0)# #(end)#. So by the Newlander-Nirenberg theorem, #(start)# #(v!x,!0,-)# #(v!x,!0)# #(end)# admits a complex structure, and complex manifolds have to be orientable. However, the Newlander-Nirenberg theorem is a deep theorem and feels a bit overkill. Also I don't really see why there cannot be a quasi-complex structure. Is there a more elementary proof to convince myself?

What would be the value of floor function of #(start)# #(lim,[n,u],-)# #(lim,[n,u])# #(lim,⌊,n,-)# #(lim,⌊,n)# #(⌊,∑,n,n)# #(⌊,∑,n)# #(∑,[n,o,u],nn)# #(∑,[n,o,u])# #(∑,f!,n,nn)# #(∑,f!,n)# #(f!,[n,o,u],nnn)# #(f!,[n,o,u])# #(f!,⌋,n,nnn)# #(f!,⌋,n)# #(⌋,!0,nnnn)# #(⌋,!0)# #(f!,n!1,o,nnn)# #(f!,n!1,o)# #(n!1,!0,nnno)# #(n!1,!0)# #(f!,n!2,u,nnn)# #(f!,n!2,u)# #(n!2,v!r,a,nnnu)# #(n!2,v!r,a)# #(v!r,!0,nnnua)# #(v!r,!0)# #(∑,v!n,o,nn)# #(∑,v!n,o)# #(v!n,!0,nno)# #(v!n,!0)# #(∑,v!r,u,nn)# #(∑,v!r,u)# #(v!r,=,n,nnu)# #(v!r,=,n)# #(=,n!1,n,nnun)# #(=,n!1,n)# #(n!1,!0,nnunn)# #(n!1,!0)# #{n!1,no,unn,nn}# #{n!1,no,unn}# #{v!r,nua,u,nn}# #{v!r,nua,u}# #(lim,v!n,u,-)# #(lim,v!n,u)# #(v!n,→,n,u)# #(v!n,→,n)# #(→,v!∞,n,un)# #(→,v!∞,n)# #(v!∞,!0,unn)# #(v!∞,!0)# #{v!n,nno,u,-}# #{v!n,nno,u}# #(end)# would it be #(start)# #(n!1,!0,-)# #(n!1,!0)# #(end)# or would it be #(start)# #(n!0,!0,-)# #(n!0,!0)# #(end)# ? The formula I use for this is that of infinite summation series that is #(start)# #(f!,[o,u],-)# #(f!,[o,u])# #(f!,v!a,o,-)# #(f!,v!a,o)# #(v!a,!0,o)# #(v!a,!0)# #(f!,n!1,u,-)# #(f!,n!1,u)# #(n!1,-,n,u)# #(n!1,-,n)# #(-,v!r,n,un)# #(-,v!r,n)# #(v!r,!0,unn)# #(v!r,!0)# #(end)# but I have no clue how to find out what the floor value of the above expression would be. P.s I am a high school student so please explain in simple terms, and yes I do know basic calculus. title: On the irrationality of Euler Mascheroni constant
body: I saw one of the expansions of Euler Mascheroni constant in terms of Meissel Mertens constant as a consequence of Mertens theorem. #(start)# #(v!b,=,n,-)# #(v!b,=,n)# #(=,v!γ,n,n)# #(=,v!γ,n)# #(v!γ,+,n,nn)# #(v!γ,+,n)# #(+,∑,n,nnn)# #(+,∑,n)# #(∑,[n,u],nnnn)# #(∑,[n,u])# #(∑,m!{}1x1,n,nnnn)# #(∑,m!{}1x1,n)# #(m!{}1x1,v!log,w,nnnnn)# #(m!{}1x1,v!log,w)# #(v!log,m!()1x1,n,5n1w)# #(v!log,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w],5n1w1n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w])# #(m!()1x1,+,n,5n1w1n)# #(m!()1x1,+,n)# #(+,f!,n,5n1w2n)# #(+,f!,n)# #(f!,[o,u],5n1w3n)# #(f!,[o,u])# #(f!,n!1,o,5n1w3n)# #(f!,n!1,o)# #(n!1,!0,5n1w3n1o)# #(n!1,!0)# #(f!,v!p,u,5n1w3n)# #(f!,v!p,u)# #(v!p,!0,5n1w3n1u)# #(v!p,!0)# #(m!()1x1,n!1,w,5n1w1n)# #(m!()1x1,n!1,w)# #(n!1,-,n,5n1w1n1w)# #(n!1,-,n)# #(-,f!,n,5n1w1n1w1n)# #(-,f!,n)# #(f!,[o,u],5n1w1n1w2n)# #(f!,[o,u])# #(f!,n!1,o,5n1w1n1w2n)# #(f!,n!1,o)# #(n!1,!0,5n1w1n1w2n1o)# #(n!1,!0)# #{n!1,nno,wnno,5n1w1n}# #{n!1,nno,wnno}# #(f!,v!p,u,5n1w1n1w2n)# #(f!,v!p,u)# #(v!p,!0,5n1w1n1w2n1u)# #(v!p,!0)# #{v!p,nnu,wnnu,5n1w1n}# #{v!p,nnu,wnnu}# #{f!,nn,wnn,5n1w1n}# #{f!,nn,wnn}# #{n!1,nno,w,5n1w1n}# #{n!1,nno,w}# #{n!1,nno,5n1w1n1w}# #{n!1,nno}# #(∑,v!p,u,nnnn)# #(∑,v!p,u)# #(v!p,!0,nnnnu)# #(v!p,!0)# #{v!p,1n1w3n1u,u,nnnn}# #{v!p,1n1w3n1u,u}# #{v!p,1n1w1n1w2n1u,u,nnnn}# #{v!p,1n1w1n1w2n1u,u}# #{+,nnwnn,nnn}# #{+,nnwnn}# #(end)# This is that expansion. Now I don't understand why is it difficult to prove the irrationality of Euler Mascheroni constant. Since we have infinitely many prime numbers, the sum over all those primes in the above equation, if converges must be a irrational, then why is it not considered as a proof of irrationality?

I know that by Cauchy's theorem we can modify a path of integration (without changing the value of the integral) starting and ending at the same point as long as we do not cross any singularity, but this path starts and ends at infinity, so I am not sure how to rigorously proceed using Cauchy's theorem. title: Number of solutions of equation over a finite field
body: I have a question regarding the number of solutions of a equation over a finite field #(start)# #(v!𝔽,v!p,b,-)# #(v!𝔽,v!p,b)# #(v!p,!0,b)# #(v!p,!0)# #(end)#. First of all, consider the equation #(start)# #(v!x,[n,a],-)# #(v!x,[n,a])# #(v!x,=,n,-)# #(v!x,=,n)# #(=,v!a,n,n)# #(=,v!a,n)# #(v!a,!0,nn)# #(v!a,!0)# #(v!x,n!3,a,-)# #(v!x,n!3,a)# #(n!3,!0,a)# #(n!3,!0)# #(end)# over #(start)# #(v!𝔽,v!p,b,-)# #(v!𝔽,v!p,b)# #(v!p,!0,b)# #(v!p,!0)# #(end)#, where #(start)# #(v!p,!0,-)# #(v!p,!0)# #(end)# is a prime such that #(start)# #(v!p,≡,n,-)# #(v!p,≡,n)# #(≡,n!2,n,n)# #(≡,n!2,n)# #(n!2,m!()1x1,n,nn)# #(n!2,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,t!mod,w,nnn)# #(m!()1x1,t!mod,w)# #(t!mod,n!3,n,nnnw)# #(t!mod,n!3,n)# #(n!3,!0,nnnwn)# #(n!3,!0)# #(end)#. The book that I'm currently reading says that this equation has exactly one solution in #(start)# #(v!𝔽,v!p,b,-)# #(v!𝔽,v!p,b)# #(v!p,!0,b)# #(v!p,!0)# #(end)# for every #(start)# #(v!a,∈,n,-)# #(v!a,∈,n)# #(∈,v!𝔽,n,n)# #(∈,v!𝔽,n)# #(v!𝔽,v!p,b,nn)# #(v!𝔽,v!p,b)# #(v!p,!0,nnb)# #(v!p,!0)# #(end)#, because #(start)# #(v!gcd,m!()1x2,n,-)# #(v!gcd,m!()1x2,n)# #(m!()1x2,[n,w],n)# #(m!()1x2,[n,w])# #(m!()1x2,=,n,n)# #(m!()1x2,=,n)# #(=,n!1,n,nn)# #(=,n!1,n)# #(n!1,!0,nnn)# #(n!1,!0)# #(m!()1x2,n!3,w,n)# #(m!()1x2,n!3,w)# #(n!3,v!p,e,nw)# #(n!3,v!p,e)# #(v!p,-,n,nwe)# #(v!p,-,n)# #(-,n!1,n,nwen)# #(-,n!1,n)# #(n!1,!0,nwenn)# #(n!1,!0)# #{n!1,nn,wenn,n}# #{n!1,nn,wenn}# #(end)#, but the book does not prove this. Unfortunately, this doesn't convince me enough. Is there is a convincing elementary straightforward proof justifying why is this true?

Is there any better way to do this?

However, I am not completely sure. Is there a law that tells me how I can solve this question? Since this is a Math Olympiad question, there is probably a maximum time limit of five minutes to do this question. This means that I probably won’t have time for tedious mathematical calculations with a calculator and online tools, or something like that. Please give me a quick, fast solution that is probably suitable for an 8th grader, at most a solution at a 10th grader level.

Obviously, because the concept of algebra isn’t aware of the fact that we are restricting the variables to positive integers, and given my assumption that the equality doesn’t necessarily hold for non-integers, an element of non-algebraic problem solving is needed, i.e. making a change to the expression given our knowledge of that condition, which then allows for algebraic maneuvers that show that the equality holds. I think that’s what I’m missing. Thanks.

Is it a correct method or have I misunderstood it?

title: Every projective module is a direct summand of free module.
body: I was reading "Serial Rings" by Gennadi Puninski. There it is written that , "Since every module is a homomorphic image of a free module, every projective module is a direct summand of free module".(ie. if #(start)# #(v!p,!0,-)# #(v!p,!0)# #(end)# is a  projective module, there exists a free module F such that, #(start)# #(v!f,=,n,-)# #(v!f,=,n)# #(=,v!p,n,n)# #(=,v!p,n)# #(v!p,⊕,n,nn)# #(v!p,⊕,n)# #(⊕,v!t,n,nnn)# #(⊕,v!t,n)# #(v!t,!0,nnnn)# #(v!t,!0)# #(end)# for some module #(start)# #(v!t,!0,-)# #(v!t,!0)# #(end)#.) But I can't understand how "Every module is a homomorphic image of a free module" implies that "Every projective module is a direct summand of free module". (I have found a proof for "Every projective module is a direct summand of free module" but the first part of the above mentioned sentence wasn't used there.)

title: Suppose that all the tangent lines of a regular plane curve pass through some fixed point. Prove that the curve is part of a straight line.
body: Question. Suppose that all the tangent lines of a regular plane curve pass through some fixed point. Prove that the curve is part of a straight line. Prove the same result if all the normal lines are parallel. I am working on differential geometry from the book by Pressley and I have a doubt in the solution of the above question whose (brief) solution is given by: Solution: We can assume that the curve #(start)# #(v!γ,!0,-)# #(v!γ,!0)# #(end)# is unit-speed and that the tangent lines all pass through the origin (by applying a translation to #(start)# #(v!γ,!0,-)# #(v!γ,!0)# #(end)#). Then, there is a scalar #(start)# #(v!λ,m!()1x1,n,-)# #(v!λ,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!t,w,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!t,w)# #(v!t,!0,nw)# #(v!t,!0)# #(end)# such that #(start)# #(v!γ,[n,a],-)# #(v!γ,[n,a])# #(v!γ,m!()1x1,n,-)# #(v!γ,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w],n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w])# #(m!()1x1,=,n,n)# #(m!()1x1,=,n)# #(=,v!λ,n,nn)# #(=,v!λ,n)# #(v!λ,m!()1x1,n,nnn)# #(v!λ,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w],nnnn)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w])# #(m!()1x1,v!γ,n,nnnn)# #(m!()1x1,v!γ,n)# #(v!γ,m!()1x1,n,nnnnn)# #(v!γ,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!t,w,6n)# #(m!()1x1,v!t,w)# #(v!t,!0,6n1w)# #(v!t,!0)# #(m!()1x1,v!t,w,nnnn)# #(m!()1x1,v!t,w)# #(v!t,!0,nnnnw)# #(v!t,!0)# #{v!t,nnw,w,nnnn}# #{v!t,nnw,w}# #{m!()1x1,nn,nnnn}# #{m!()1x1,nn}# #(m!()1x1,v!t,w,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!t,w)# #(v!t,!0,nw)# #(v!t,!0)# #{v!t,5n1w,w,n}# #{v!t,5n1w,w}# #{v!t,nnnw,w,n}# #{v!t,nnnw,w}# #{m!()1x1,nnnnn,n}# #{m!()1x1,nnnnn}# #{m!()1x1,nnn,n}# #{m!()1x1,nnn}# #(v!γ,′,a,-)# #(v!γ,′,a)# #(′,!0,a)# #(′,!0)# #{v!γ,nnnnn,-}# #{v!γ,nnnnn}# #(end)# for all #(start)# #(v!t,!0,-)# #(v!t,!0)# #(end)#. Then, #(start)# #(v!γ,[n,a],-)# #(v!γ,[n,a])# #(v!γ,=,n,-)# #(v!γ,=,n)# #(=,v!λ,n,n)# #(=,v!λ,n)# #(v!λ,[n,a],nn)# #(v!λ,[n,a])# #(v!λ,v!γ,n,nn)# #(v!λ,v!γ,n)# #(v!γ,+,n,nnn)# #(v!γ,+,n)# #(+,v!λ,n,nnnn)# #(+,v!λ,n)# #(v!λ,v!γ,n,nnnnn)# #(v!λ,v!γ,n)# #(v!γ,[n,a],6n)# #(v!γ,[n,a])# #(v!γ,=,n,6n)# #(v!γ,=,n)# #(=,m!()1x1,n,7n)# #(=,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w],8n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w])# #(m!()1x1,v!γ,n,8n)# #(m!()1x1,v!γ,n)# #(v!γ,!0,9n)# #(v!γ,!0)# #(m!()1x1,v!λ,w,8n)# #(m!()1x1,v!λ,w)# #(v!λ,[n,a],8n1w)# #(v!λ,[n,a])# #(v!λ,+,n,8n1w)# #(v!λ,+,n)# #(+,v!λ,n,8n1w1n)# #(+,v!λ,n)# #(v!λ,n!2,a,8n1w2n)# #(v!λ,n!2,a)# #(n!2,!0,8n1w2n1a)# #(n!2,!0)# #(v!λ,′,a,8n1w)# #(v!λ,′,a)# #(′,!0,8n1w1a)# #(′,!0)# #{v!λ,nn,8n1w}# #{v!λ,nn}# #(v!γ,′,a,6n)# #(v!γ,′,a)# #(′,!0,6n1a)# #(′,!0)# #{′,nnwa,a,6n}# #{′,nnwa,a}# #{v!γ,nnn,6n}# #{v!γ,nnn}# #{v!λ,3n1w2n,nnnnn}# #{v!λ,3n1w2n}# #{v!λ,nnnw,nnnnn}# #{v!λ,nnnw}# #{+,4n1w1n,nnnn}# #{+,4n1w1n}# #{v!γ,6n,nnn}# #{v!γ,6n}# #{v!γ,nnn,nnn}# #{v!γ,nnn}# #(v!λ,′,a,nn)# #(v!λ,′,a)# #(′,!0,nna)# #(′,!0)# #{′,6n1w1a,a,nn}# #{′,6n1w1a,a}# #{′,nnnna,a,nn}# #{′,nnnna,a}# #{v!λ,6n1w2n,nn}# #{v!λ,6n1w2n}# #{v!λ,6n1w,nn}# #{v!λ,6n1w}# #{v!λ,nnn,nn}# #{v!λ,nnn}# #{=,6n,n}# #{=,6n}# #(v!γ,′′,a,-)# #(v!γ,′′,a)# #(′′,!0,a)# #(′′,!0)# #{v!γ,9n,-}# #{v!γ,9n}# #{v!γ,6n,-}# #{v!γ,6n}# #{v!γ,nnn,-}# #{v!γ,nnn}# #(end)#. Can anyone please explain me how does this line follow : " Then, there is a scalar #(start)# #(v!λ,m!()1x1,n,-)# #(v!λ,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!t,w,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!t,w)# #(v!t,!0,nw)# #(v!t,!0)# #(end)# such that #(start)# #(v!γ,[n,a],-)# #(v!γ,[n,a])# #(v!γ,m!()1x1,n,-)# #(v!γ,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w],n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w])# #(m!()1x1,=,n,n)# #(m!()1x1,=,n)# #(=,v!λ,n,nn)# #(=,v!λ,n)# #(v!λ,m!()1x1,n,nnn)# #(v!λ,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w],nnnn)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w])# #(m!()1x1,v!γ,n,nnnn)# #(m!()1x1,v!γ,n)# #(v!γ,m!()1x1,n,nnnnn)# #(v!γ,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!t,w,6n)# #(m!()1x1,v!t,w)# #(v!t,!0,6n1w)# #(v!t,!0)# #(m!()1x1,v!t,w,nnnn)# #(m!()1x1,v!t,w)# #(v!t,!0,nnnnw)# #(v!t,!0)# #{v!t,nnw,w,nnnn}# #{v!t,nnw,w}# #{m!()1x1,nn,nnnn}# #{m!()1x1,nn}# #(m!()1x1,v!t,w,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!t,w)# #(v!t,!0,nw)# #(v!t,!0)# #{v!t,5n1w,w,n}# #{v!t,5n1w,w}# #{v!t,nnnw,w,n}# #{v!t,nnnw,w}# #{m!()1x1,nnnnn,n}# #{m!()1x1,nnnnn}# #{m!()1x1,nnn,n}# #{m!()1x1,nnn}# #(v!γ,′,a,-)# #(v!γ,′,a)# #(′,!0,a)# #(′,!0)# #{v!γ,nnnnn,-}# #{v!γ,nnnnn}# #(end)# for all #(start)# #(v!t,!0,-)# #(v!t,!0)# #(end)#." title: Extension of Euclid's lemma
body: This is#(start)# #(v!a,!0,-)# #(v!a,!0)# #(end)#somewhat obvious fact that is intuitively obvious to me, but I haven't been able to construct a proof of it. Euclid's lemma states for for #(start)# #(v!p,!0,-)# #(v!p,!0)# #(end)# a prime and #(start)# #(v!a,v!b,n,-)# #(v!a,v!b,n)# #(v!b,!0,n)# #(v!b,!0)# #(end)# a product of integers (let's take everything to be positive for simplicity), if #(start)# #(v!p,∣,n,-)# #(v!p,∣,n)# #(∣,v!a,n,n)# #(∣,v!a,n)# #(v!a,v!b,n,nn)# #(v!a,v!b,n)# #(v!b,!0,nnn)# #(v!b,!0)# #(end)#, then #(start)# #(v!p,∣,n,-)# #(v!p,∣,n)# #(∣,v!a,n,n)# #(∣,v!a,n)# #(v!a,!0,nn)# #(v!a,!0)# #(end)# or #(start)# #(v!p,∣,n,-)# #(v!p,∣,n)# #(∣,v!b,n,n)# #(∣,v!b,n)# #(v!b,!0,nn)# #(v!b,!0)# #(end)#. This is clear, and I know how to prove it. Let's extend it somewhat. Suppose that  and #(start)# #(v!b,!0,-)# #(v!b,!0)# #(end)# are two relatively prime integers, and we have #(start)# #(v!a,∣,n,-)# #(v!a,∣,n)# #(∣,v!b,n,n)# #(∣,v!b,n)# #(v!b,v!c,n,nn)# #(v!b,v!c,n)# #(v!c,!0,nnn)# #(v!c,!0)# #(end)# for some other integer #(start)# #(v!c,!0,-)# #(v!c,!0)# #(end)#. Then #(start)# #(v!a,∤,n,-)# #(v!a,∤,n)# #(∤,v!b,n,n)# #(∤,v!b,n)# #(v!b,!0,nn)# #(v!b,!0)# #(end)#, so it must divide #(start)# #(v!c,!0,-)# #(v!c,!0)# #(end)#. This fact is obvious to me, but I can't figure out how to prove it. Does anyone have any hints or advice? Do I need the assumption of positivity? (For my purposes at the moment, I only need them to be positive, but there is value in having the most general result possible). EDIT: Updated attempt: We have that #(start)# #(v!a,comma,n,-)# #(v!a,comma,n)# #(comma,v!b,n,n)# #(comma,v!b,n)# #(v!b,!0,nn)# #(v!b,!0)# #(end)# are relatively prime, so there exist #(start)# #(v!r,comma,n,-)# #(v!r,comma,n)# #(comma,v!s,n,n)# #(comma,v!s,n)# #(v!s,∈,n,nn)# #(v!s,∈,n)# #(∈,v!ℤ,n,nnn)# #(∈,v!ℤ,n)# #(v!ℤ,!0,nnnn)# #(v!ℤ,!0)# #(end)# such that #(start)# #(v!a,v!r,n,-)# #(v!a,v!r,n)# #(v!r,+,n,n)# #(v!r,+,n)# #(+,v!b,n,nn)# #(+,v!b,n)# #(v!b,v!s,n,nnn)# #(v!b,v!s,n)# #(v!s,=,n,nnnn)# #(v!s,=,n)# #(=,n!1,n,nnnnn)# #(=,n!1,n)# #(n!1,!0,6n)# #(n!1,!0)# #(end)# by Bézout's lemma. Multiply through by #(start)# #(v!c,!0,-)# #(v!c,!0)# #(end)# to get #(start)# #(v!a,v!r,n,-)# #(v!a,v!r,n)# #(v!r,v!c,n,n)# #(v!r,v!c,n)# #(v!c,+,n,nn)# #(v!c,+,n)# #(+,v!b,n,nnn)# #(+,v!b,n)# #(v!b,v!s,n,nnnn)# #(v!b,v!s,n)# #(v!s,v!c,n,nnnnn)# #(v!s,v!c,n)# #(v!c,=,n,6n)# #(v!c,=,n)# #(=,v!c,n,7n)# #(=,v!c,n)# #(v!c,!0,8n)# #(v!c,!0)# #{v!c,nn,6n}# #{v!c,nn}# #{v!c,6n,nn}# #{v!c,6n}# #{v!c,nnnn,nn}# #{v!c,nnnn}# #(end)#. And the relation on the title:  We must prove that this is a Cauchy sequence. I know that an Cauchy sequence follows the definition: given #(start)# #(v!ϵ,gt,n,-)# #(v!ϵ,gt,n)# #(gt,n!0,n,n)# #(gt,n!0,n)# #(n!0,!0,nn)# #(n!0,!0)# #(end)#, exists #(start)# #(v!n,[n,b],-)# #(v!n,[n,b])# #(v!n,gt,n,-)# #(v!n,gt,n)# #(gt,n!0,n,n)# #(gt,n!0,n)# #(n!0,!0,nn)# #(n!0,!0)# #(v!n,n!0,b,-)# #(v!n,n!0,b)# #(n!0,!0,b)# #(n!0,!0)# #{n!0,nn,b,-}# #{n!0,nn,b}# #(end)#, such that  But I don't know how to use both informations to prove the exercise. If someone please may help me, I'd be very thankful.

body: In four sections of a course, running (independently) in parallel, there are four students giving presentations that are each Exponential in length, with expected value of#(start)# #(n!10,!0,-)# #(n!10,!0)# #(end)#minutes each. How much time do we expect to be needed until all four of the presentations are completed? I'm a little thrown off by this question since it's in the chapter of order statistics in my book. But I believe that this is just gamma distribution. If each student has expected value of  minutes each. title: When two dice are identical, why are ordered pairs considered for determining probability of getting sum x?
Any collection of subsets of a set is a subbasis for a topology
body: Theorem Any collection of subsets #(start)# #(v!𝒜,!0,-)# #(v!𝒜,!0)# #(end)# of a nonempty set #(start)# #(v!x,!0,-)# #(v!x,!0)# #(end)# forms the subbasis for a unique topology #(start)# #(v!τ,!0,-)# #(v!τ,!0)# #(end)# on #(start)# #(v!x,!0,-)# #(v!x,!0)# #(end)#. This theorem is absolutely amazing to me. I really enjoy the idea of it as a powerful tool, but I have come up with a counterexample that I just can't get over. So the theorem states that any collection of subsets of a nonempty #(start)# #(v!x,!0,-)# #(v!x,!0)# #(end)# form a subbasis for a unique topology on #(start)# #(v!x,!0,-)# #(v!x,!0)# #(end)#. The emphasis there is any. So, consider the following counterexample: Let #(start)# #(v!x,=,n,-)# #(v!x,=,n)# #(=,m!{}1x5,n,n)# #(=,m!{}1x5,n)# #(m!{}1x5,v!a,w,nn)# #(m!{}1x5,v!a,w)# #(v!a,v!b,e,nnw)# #(v!a,v!b,e)# #(v!b,v!c,e,nnwe)# #(v!b,v!c,e)# #(v!c,v!d,e,nnwee)# #(v!c,v!d,e)# #(v!d,v!e,e,2n1w3e)# #(v!d,v!e,e)# #(v!e,!0,2n1w4e)# #(v!e,!0)# #(end)# and let #(start)# #(v!𝒜,=,n,-)# #(v!𝒜,=,n)# #(=,m!{}1x1,n,n)# #(=,m!{}1x1,n)# #(m!{}1x1,m!{}1x1,w,nn)# #(m!{}1x1,m!{}1x1,w)# #(m!{}1x1,v!a,w,nnw)# #(m!{}1x1,v!a,w)# #(v!a,!0,nnww)# #(v!a,!0)# #{m!{}1x1,w,nn}# #{m!{}1x1,w}# #(end)#. Clearly, this is a collection of subsets of #(start)# #(v!x,!0,-)# #(v!x,!0)# #(end)#. Assume that, by our theorem, then #(start)# #(v!𝒜,=,n,-)# #(v!𝒜,=,n)# #(=,m!{}1x1,n,n)# #(=,m!{}1x1,n)# #(m!{}1x1,m!{}1x1,w,nn)# #(m!{}1x1,m!{}1x1,w)# #(m!{}1x1,v!a,w,nnw)# #(m!{}1x1,v!a,w)# #(v!a,!0,nnww)# #(v!a,!0)# #{m!{}1x1,w,nn}# #{m!{}1x1,w}# #(end)# is a subbasis for some topology on #(start)# #(v!x,!0,-)# #(v!x,!0)# #(end)#. Okay, so since #(start)# #(v!𝒜,!0,-)# #(v!𝒜,!0)# #(end)# is a subbasis of some topology on #(start)# #(v!x,!0,-)# #(v!x,!0)# #(end)#, let's try taking intersections of members of #(start)# #(v!𝒜,!0,-)# #(v!𝒜,!0)# #(end)#. Well, #(start)# #(m!{}1x1,[n,w],-)# #(m!{}1x1,[n,w])# #(m!{}1x1,∩,n,-)# #(m!{}1x1,∩,n)# #(∩,m!{}1x1,n,n)# #(∩,m!{}1x1,n)# #(m!{}1x1,[n,w],nn)# #(m!{}1x1,[n,w])# #(m!{}1x1,=,n,nn)# #(m!{}1x1,=,n)# #(=,m!{}1x1,n,nnn)# #(=,m!{}1x1,n)# #(m!{}1x1,v!a,w,nnnn)# #(m!{}1x1,v!a,w)# #(v!a,!0,nnnnw)# #(v!a,!0)# #(m!{}1x1,v!a,w,nn)# #(m!{}1x1,v!a,w)# #(v!a,!0,nnw)# #(v!a,!0)# #{v!a,nnw,w,nn}# #{v!a,nnw,w}# #{m!{}1x1,nn,nn}# #{m!{}1x1,nn}# #(m!{}1x1,v!a,w,-)# #(m!{}1x1,v!a,w)# #(v!a,!0,w)# #(v!a,!0)# #{v!a,nnnnw,w,-}# #{v!a,nnnnw,w}# #{v!a,nnw,w,-}# #{v!a,nnw,w}# #{m!{}1x1,nnnn,-}# #{m!{}1x1,nnnn}# #{m!{}1x1,nn,-}# #{m!{}1x1,nn}# #(end)#. Then our basis for our topology is #(start)# #(v!ℬ,=,n,-)# #(v!ℬ,=,n)# #(=,m!{}1x1,n,n)# #(=,m!{}1x1,n)# #(m!{}1x1,m!{}1x1,w,nn)# #(m!{}1x1,m!{}1x1,w)# #(m!{}1x1,v!a,w,nnw)# #(m!{}1x1,v!a,w)# #(v!a,!0,nnww)# #(v!a,!0)# #{m!{}1x1,w,nn}# #{m!{}1x1,w}# #(end)# This is problematic because this means that our basis #(start)# #(v!ℬ,!0,-)# #(v!ℬ,!0)# #(end)# is just #(start)# #(m!{}1x1,v!a,w,-)# #(m!{}1x1,v!a,w)# #(v!a,!0,w)# #(v!a,!0)# #(end)#, but note that #(start)# #(⋃,v!ℬ,n,-)# #(⋃,v!ℬ,n)# #(v!ℬ,=,n,n)# #(v!ℬ,=,n)# #(=,m!{}1x1,n,nn)# #(=,m!{}1x1,n)# #(m!{}1x1,v!a,w,nnn)# #(m!{}1x1,v!a,w)# #(v!a,!0,nnnw)# #(v!a,!0)# #(end)# and #(start)# #(m!{}1x1,[n,w],-)# #(m!{}1x1,[n,w])# #(m!{}1x1,≠,n,-)# #(m!{}1x1,≠,n)# #(≠,v!x,n,n)# #(≠,v!x,n)# #(v!x,.,n,nn)# #(v!x,.,n)# #(.,!0,nnn)# #(.,!0)# #(m!{}1x1,v!a,w,-)# #(m!{}1x1,v!a,w)# #(v!a,!0,w)# #(v!a,!0)# #(end)# Therefore, #(start)# #(v!x,∉,n,-)# #(v!x,∉,n)# #(∉,v!τ,n,n)# #(∉,v!τ,n)# #(v!τ,.,n,nn)# #(v!τ,.,n)# #(.,!0,nnn)# #(.,!0)# #(end)# How do we get #(start)# #(v!x,!0,-)# #(v!x,!0)# #(end)# in #(start)# #(v!τ,!0,-)# #(v!τ,!0)# #(end)#? Is my counterexample logically consistent?

title: Elementary geometry question: How to calculate distance between two skew lines?
body: I am helping someone with highschool maths but I got stacked in a elementary geometry problem. First I am asked the relative position of them so I get they are skew lines. After that I am asked for the distance between the two lines. In order to get the distance I have to calculate the line that is perpendicular to both of them in the "skewing" point, check the points where it touches the other two lines (sorry, not sure about the word in English) and calculate the module of this vector. Im having trouble calculating the perpendicular line. I know I can get the director vector using vectorial product, but  I'm not sure how to find a point so that I can build the line.

So I am supposed to be proving that if #(start)# #(v!p,n!1,b,-)# #(v!p,n!1,b)# #(n!1,!0,b)# #(n!1,!0)# #(end)# and #(start)# #(v!p,n!2,b,-)# #(v!p,n!2,b)# #(n!2,!0,b)# #(n!2,!0)# #(end)# are distinct primes and #(start)# #(v!p,[n,b],-)# #(v!p,[n,b])# #(v!p,∣,n,-)# #(v!p,∣,n)# #(∣,v!a,n,n)# #(∣,v!a,n)# #(v!a,!0,nn)# #(v!a,!0)# #(v!p,n!1,b,-)# #(v!p,n!1,b)# #(n!1,!0,b)# #(n!1,!0)# #(end)# and #(start)# #(v!p,[n,b],-)# #(v!p,[n,b])# #(v!p,∣,n,-)# #(v!p,∣,n)# #(∣,v!a,n,n)# #(∣,v!a,n)# #(v!a,!0,nn)# #(v!a,!0)# #(v!p,n!2,b,-)# #(v!p,n!2,b)# #(n!2,!0,b)# #(n!2,!0)# #(end)# then #(start)# #(v!p,[n,b],-)# #(v!p,[n,b])# #(v!p,v!p,n,-)# #(v!p,v!p,n)# #(v!p,[n,b],n)# #(v!p,[n,b])# #(v!p,∣,n,n)# #(v!p,∣,n)# #(∣,v!a,n,nn)# #(∣,v!a,n)# #(v!a,!0,nnn)# #(v!a,!0)# #(v!p,n!2,b,n)# #(v!p,n!2,b)# #(n!2,!0,nb)# #(n!2,!0)# #(v!p,n!1,b,-)# #(v!p,n!1,b)# #(n!1,!0,b)# #(n!1,!0)# #{v!p,n,-}# #{v!p,n}# #(end)#, and I need to use Euclid's Lemma except as far as I understand Euclid's lemma is the converse of this statement and I have tried for the last few hours to work with Euclid's and GCDs to figure this one out and I just don't know where to start since I can't wrap my head around this one. Can anyone help me out?

Find all functions #(start)# #(v!f,:,n,-)# #(v!f,:,n)# #(:,v!ℝ,n,n)# #(:,v!ℝ,n)# #(v!ℝ,→,n,nn)# #(v!ℝ,→,n)# #(→,v!ℝ,n,nnn)# #(→,v!ℝ,n)# #(v!ℝ,!0,nnnn)# #(v!ℝ,!0)# #{v!ℝ,nn,nn}# #{v!ℝ,nn}# #(end)# such that #(start)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n,-)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w],n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w])# #(m!()1x1,=,n,n)# #(m!()1x1,=,n)# #(=,v!x,n,nn)# #(=,v!x,n)# #(v!x,v!f,n,nnn)# #(v!x,v!f,n)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n,nnnn)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w],nnnnn)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w])# #(m!()1x1,+,n,nnnnn)# #(m!()1x1,+,n)# #(+,v!y,n,6n)# #(+,v!y,n)# #(v!y,!0,7n)# #(v!y,!0)# #(m!()1x1,v!x,w,nnnnn)# #(m!()1x1,v!x,w)# #(v!x,!0,5n1w)# #(v!x,!0)# #{v!x,nnw,nnn}# #{v!x,nnw}# #(m!()1x1,v!f,w,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!f,w)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n,nw)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,a,w],nwn)# #(m!()1x1,[n,a,w])# #(m!()1x1,+,n,nwn)# #(m!()1x1,+,n)# #(+,v!f,n,nwnn)# #(+,v!f,n)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n,nwnnn)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!y,w,1n1w4n)# #(m!()1x1,v!y,w)# #(v!y,!0,1n1w4n1w)# #(v!y,!0)# #{v!y,6n,1w4n1w,n}# #{v!y,6n,1w4n1w}# #{m!()1x1,nnnn,wnnnn,n}# #{m!()1x1,nnnn,wnnnn}# #{v!f,nnn,wnnn,n}# #{v!f,nnn,wnnn}# #{+,nnnnn,wnn,n}# #{+,nnnnn,wnn}# #(m!()1x1,n!2,a,nwn)# #(m!()1x1,n!2,a)# #(n!2,!0,nwna)# #(n!2,!0)# #(m!()1x1,v!x,w,nwn)# #(m!()1x1,v!x,w)# #(v!x,!0,nwnw)# #(v!x,!0)# #{v!x,nnnnw,wnw,n}# #{v!x,nnnnw,wnw}# #{v!x,nn,wnw,n}# #{v!x,nn,wnw}# #{m!()1x1,nnnn,wn,n}# #{m!()1x1,nnnn,wn}# #{m!()1x1,nnn,nwn}# #{m!()1x1,nnn}# #{v!f,nnn,w,n}# #{v!f,nnn,w}# #{v!f,nnn,nw}# #{v!f,nnn}# #{m!()1x1,nnnn,n}# #{m!()1x1,nnnn}# #{m!()1x1,wnnnn,n}# #{m!()1x1,wnnnn}# #{m!()1x1,wn,n}# #{m!()1x1,wn}# #{v!f,nnnn,-}# #{v!f,nnnn}# #{v!f,nwnnn,-}# #{v!f,nwnnn}# #{v!f,nw,-}# #{v!f,nw}# #(end)# for all #(start)# #(v!x,comma,n,-)# #(v!x,comma,n)# #(comma,v!y,n,n)# #(comma,v!y,n)# #(v!y,∈,n,nn)# #(v!y,∈,n)# #(∈,v!ℝ,n,nnn)# #(∈,v!ℝ,n)# #(v!ℝ,!0,nnnn)# #(v!ℝ,!0)# #(end)#.  Here is my approach to the problem:  We see that #(start)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n,-)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w],n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w])# #(m!()1x1,=,n,n)# #(m!()1x1,=,n)# #(=,v!x,n,nn)# #(=,v!x,n)# #(v!x,!0,nnn)# #(v!x,!0)# #(m!()1x1,v!x,w,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!x,w)# #(v!x,!0,nw)# #(v!x,!0)# #{v!x,nn,w,n}# #{v!x,nn,w}# #(end)# is an obvious solution (Just trying easy linear equations). I think this would be the only solution to the problem.  Am I right? And how to prove that there is no other solution? (Note: I am a beginner at functional equations)

title: How many functions can be used to describe to a finite series?
body: I was learning more about series today and would like to know if there are existing proofs I could look at about this problem. Basically, if you are given an infinite series representing a function f : #(start)# #(v!ℕ,⇒,n,-)# #(v!ℕ,⇒,n)# #(⇒,v!ℝ,n,n)# #(⇒,v!ℝ,n)# #(v!ℝ,!0,nn)# #(v!ℝ,!0)# #(end)# but only shown the first n numbers, how many functions f, written in terms of n, could you write to represent that series. I'm not including piecewise functions, because I assume that would always be infinite. Take the series #(start)# #(m!()1x3,n!2,w,-)# #(m!()1x3,n!2,w)# #(n!2,n!4,e,w)# #(n!2,n!4,e)# #(n!4,v!…,e,we)# #(n!4,v!…,e)# #(v!…,!0,wee)# #(v!…,!0)# #(end)# with 2 numbers given. #(start)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n,-)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w],n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w])# #(m!()1x1,=,n,n)# #(m!()1x1,=,n)# #(=,n!2,n,nn)# #(=,n!2,n)# #(n!2,v!n,n,nnn)# #(n!2,v!n,n)# #(v!n,!0,nnnn)# #(v!n,!0)# #(m!()1x1,v!n,w,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!n,w)# #(v!n,!0,nw)# #(v!n,!0)# #{v!n,nnn,w,n}# #{v!n,nnn,w}# #(end)# , #(start)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n,-)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w],n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w])# #(m!()1x1,=,n,n)# #(m!()1x1,=,n)# #(=,v!n,n,nn)# #(=,v!n,n)# #(v!n,[n,a],nnn)# #(v!n,[n,a])# #(v!n,-,n,nnn)# #(v!n,-,n)# #(-,v!n,n,nnnn)# #(-,v!n,n)# #(v!n,+,n,nnnnn)# #(v!n,+,n)# #(+,n!2,n,6n)# #(+,n!2,n)# #(n!2,!0,7n)# #(n!2,!0)# #(v!n,n!2,a,nnn)# #(v!n,n!2,a)# #(n!2,!0,nnna)# #(n!2,!0)# #{n!2,nnnn,a,nnn}# #{n!2,nnnn,a}# #{v!n,nn,nnn}# #{v!n,nn}# #(m!()1x1,v!n,w,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!n,w)# #(v!n,!0,nw)# #(v!n,!0)# #{v!n,nnnn,w,n}# #{v!n,nnnn,w}# #{v!n,nn,w,n}# #{v!n,nn,w}# #(end)# , and #(start)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n,-)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w],n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w])# #(m!()1x1,=,n,n)# #(m!()1x1,=,n)# #(=,n!2,n,nn)# #(=,n!2,n)# #(n!2,v!n,a,nnn)# #(n!2,v!n,a)# #(v!n,!0,nnna)# #(v!n,!0)# #(m!()1x1,v!n,w,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!n,w)# #(v!n,!0,nw)# #(v!n,!0)# #{v!n,nna,w,n}# #{v!n,nna,w}# #(end)# would all be functions that could fit this series, although they differ after the first two numbers. I believe there are more polynomials that fit this description but I'm not sure how many. My question is, essentially, are there an infinite number of functions for which #(start)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n,-)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w],n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w])# #(m!()1x1,=,n,n)# #(m!()1x1,=,n)# #(=,n!2,n,nn)# #(=,n!2,n)# #(n!2,!0,nnn)# #(n!2,!0)# #(m!()1x1,n!1,w,n)# #(m!()1x1,n!1,w)# #(n!1,!0,nw)# #(n!1,!0)# #(end)# and #(start)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n,-)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w],n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w])# #(m!()1x1,=,n,n)# #(m!()1x1,=,n)# #(=,n!4,n,nn)# #(=,n!4,n)# #(n!4,!0,nnn)# #(n!4,!0)# #(m!()1x1,n!2,w,n)# #(m!()1x1,n!2,w)# #(n!2,!0,nw)# #(n!2,!0)# #(end)#, and if this is the case, does this also apply to any finite number of outputs? (e.g. the first n digits of pi written as #(start)# #(m!()1x6,n!3,w,-)# #(m!()1x6,n!3,w)# #(n!3,n!1,e,w)# #(n!3,n!1,e)# #(n!1,n!4,e,we)# #(n!1,n!4,e)# #(n!4,n!1,e,wee)# #(n!4,n!1,e)# #(n!1,n!5,e,weee)# #(n!1,n!5,e)# #(n!5,n!9,e,weeee)# #(n!5,n!9,e)# #(n!9,v!…,n,1w5e)# #(n!9,v!…,n)# #(v!…,!0,1w5e1n)# #(v!…,!0)# #{n!1,ee,we}# #{n!1,ee}# #(end)#) If not, could you find out how many possible functions there are?

title: Confusion about the formula of the area of a surface of revolution
body: Before I read the formula of the area of revolution which is #(start)# #(∫,n!2,n,-)# #(∫,n!2,n)# #(n!2,v!π,n,n)# #(n!2,v!π,n)# #(v!π,v!y,n,nn)# #(v!π,v!y,n)# #(v!y,𝑑,n,nnn)# #(v!y,𝑑,n)# #(𝑑,v!s,n,nnnn)# #(𝑑,v!s,n)# #(v!s,!0,nnnnn)# #(v!s,!0)# #(end)#, where #(start)# #(v!d,v!s,n,-)# #(v!d,v!s,n)# #(v!s,=,n,n)# #(v!s,=,n)# #(=,r!,n,nn)# #(=,r!,n)# #(r!,n!1,w,nnn)# #(r!,n!1,w)# #(n!1,+,n,nnnw)# #(n!1,+,n)# #(+,f!,n,nnnwn)# #(+,f!,n)# #(f!,[a,o,u],3n1w2n)# #(f!,[a,o,u])# #(f!,n!2,a,3n1w2n)# #(f!,n!2,a)# #(n!2,!0,3n1w2n1a)# #(n!2,!0)# #(f!,v!d,o,3n1w2n)# #(f!,v!d,o)# #(v!d,v!y,n,3n1w2n1o)# #(v!d,v!y,n)# #(v!y,!0,3n1w2n1o1n)# #(v!y,!0)# #(f!,v!d,u,3n1w2n)# #(f!,v!d,u)# #(v!d,v!x,n,3n1w2n1u)# #(v!d,v!x,n)# #(v!x,!0,3n1w2n1u1n)# #(v!x,!0)# #{v!d,o,u,3n1w2n}# #{v!d,o,u}# #{v!d,3n1w2n1o,-}# #{v!d,3n1w2n1o}# #{v!d,3n1w2n1u,-}# #{v!d,3n1w2n1u}# #(end)#, I thought of deriving it myself. I tried to apply the same logic used for calculating the volume of revolution (e.g., #(start)# #(∫,v!π,n,-)# #(∫,v!π,n)# #(v!π,v!y,n,n)# #(v!π,v!y,n)# #(v!y,[n,a],nn)# #(v!y,[n,a])# #(v!y,𝑑,n,nn)# #(v!y,𝑑,n)# #(𝑑,v!x,n,nnn)# #(𝑑,v!x,n)# #(v!x,!0,nnnn)# #(v!x,!0)# #(v!y,n!2,a,nn)# #(v!y,n!2,a)# #(n!2,!0,nna)# #(n!2,!0)# #(end)#). My idea is to use many tiny hollow cylinders (inspired from the shell method), each has a surface area of #(start)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w],-)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w])# #(m!()1x1,m!()1x1,n,-)# #(m!()1x1,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!d,w,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!d,w)# #(v!d,v!x,n,nw)# #(v!d,v!x,n)# #(v!x,!0,nwn)# #(v!x,!0)# #(m!()1x1,n!2,w,-)# #(m!()1x1,n!2,w)# #(n!2,v!π,n,w)# #(n!2,v!π,n)# #(v!π,v!y,n,wn)# #(v!π,v!y,n)# #(v!y,!0,wnn)# #(v!y,!0)# #{m!()1x1,n,-}# #{m!()1x1,n}# #(end)#:  #(start)# #(n!2,v!π,n,-)# #(n!2,v!π,n)# #(v!π,v!y,n,n)# #(v!π,v!y,n)# #(v!y,!0,nn)# #(v!y,!0)# #(end)# is the circumference of the cylinder, and #(start)# #(v!d,v!x,n,-)# #(v!d,v!x,n)# #(v!x,!0,n)# #(v!x,!0)# #(end)# is the height of the cylinder  Their product is the surface area of the hollow (e.g., empty from the inside) cylinder. With this logic, the area is #(start)# #(∫,n!2,n,-)# #(∫,n!2,n)# #(n!2,v!π,n,n)# #(n!2,v!π,n)# #(v!π,v!y,n,nn)# #(v!π,v!y,n)# #(v!y,𝑑,n,nnn)# #(v!y,𝑑,n)# #(𝑑,v!x,n,nnnn)# #(𝑑,v!x,n)# #(v!x,!0,nnnnn)# #(v!x,!0)# #(end)#. Where is my mistake? Also it's confusing why for the volume it was enough to partition the object using cylinders and for areas not.

title: Apparent inconsistencies in integration
body: In a problem, the substitution #(start)# #(v!tan,v!θ,n,-)# #(v!tan,v!θ,n)# #(v!θ,=,n,n)# #(v!θ,=,n)# #(=,f!,n,nn)# #(=,f!,n)# #(f!,[o,u],nnn)# #(f!,[o,u])# #(f!,v!x,o,nnn)# #(f!,v!x,o)# #(v!x,!0,nnno)# #(v!x,!0)# #(f!,n!2,u,nnn)# #(f!,n!2,u)# #(n!2,!0,nnnu)# #(n!2,!0)# #(end)# was made. In the end, the answer was in terms of sines, and to convert back, #(start)# #(v!s,v!i,n,-)# #(v!s,v!i,n)# #(v!i,v!n,n,n)# #(v!i,v!n,n)# #(v!n,v!θ,n,nn)# #(v!n,v!θ,n)# #(v!θ,!0,nnn)# #(v!θ,!0)# #(end)# was defined as #(start)# #(v!sin,v!θ,n,-)# #(v!sin,v!θ,n)# #(v!θ,=,n,n)# #(v!θ,=,n)# #(=,f!,n,nn)# #(=,f!,n)# #(f!,[o,u],nnn)# #(f!,[o,u])# #(f!,v!x,o,nnn)# #(f!,v!x,o)# #(v!x,!0,nnno)# #(v!x,!0)# #(f!,r!,u,nnn)# #(f!,r!,u)# #(r!,n!4,w,nnnu)# #(r!,n!4,w)# #(n!4,+,n,nnnuw)# #(n!4,+,n)# #(+,v!x,n,3n1u1w1n)# #(+,v!x,n)# #(v!x,n!2,a,3n1u1w2n)# #(v!x,n!2,a)# #(n!2,!0,3n1u1w2n1a)# #(n!2,!0)# #{v!x,o,uwnn,nnn}# #{v!x,o,uwnn}# #(end)# This is a typical example of some stuff about integration I'm struggling to understand; (1) Why are the absolute values of square roots never taken? This is something I keep seeing in every situation involving an integral. (Here, if #(start)# #(v!θ,!0,-)# #(v!θ,!0)# #(end)# is in the third quadrant, sines would be negative and tans would be positive. So this definitely doesn't work for the third quadrant.) (2) Expanding upon the stuff in the parantheses up there, a possible explanation is that while doing trig substitutions, the angle is always a principal angle of the inverse trigonometric operation on whatever you're making the substitution. Is there such a rule?

title: Fourier transform of function #(start)# #(n!1,/,n,-)# #(n!1,/,n)# #(/,m!||1x1,n,n)# #(/,m!||1x1,n)# #(m!||1x1,v!x,w,nn)# #(m!||1x1,v!x,w)# #(v!x,!0,nnw)# #(v!x,!0)# #(end)#
body: What is the Fourier transform of function #(start)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n,-)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w],n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w])# #(m!()1x1,=,n,n)# #(m!()1x1,=,n)# #(=,f!,n,nn)# #(=,f!,n)# #(f!,[n,o,u],nnn)# #(f!,[n,o,u])# #(f!,v!qvar_$,n,nnn)# #(f!,v!qvar_$,n)# #(v!qvar_$,!0,nnnn)# #(v!qvar_$,!0)# #(f!,n!1,o,nnn)# #(f!,n!1,o)# #(n!1,!0,nnno)# #(n!1,!0)# #(f!,m!||1x1,u,nnn)# #(f!,m!||1x1,u)# #(m!||1x1,v!x,w,nnnu)# #(m!||1x1,v!x,w)# #(v!x,!0,nnnuw)# #(v!x,!0)# #(m!()1x1,v!x,w,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!x,w)# #(v!x,!0,nw)# #(v!x,!0)# #{v!x,nnuw,w,n}# #{v!x,nnuw,w}# #(end)# This is not a homework. I would also appreciate help for calculating it myself.

title: Is a Riemann-integrable function always differentiable?

title: Kuratowski's Theorem using Axiom of Choice
body: I can't seem to be able to prove Kuratowski's Theorem using the Axiom of Choice, although they are equivalent assertions. Kuratowski's Lemma: Every partial order has a maximal chain. Axiom of Choice: For every set X of disjoint nonempty sets there exists a set#(start)# #(v!y,!0,-)# #(v!y,!0)# #(end)#such that for every set #(start)# #(v!z,∈,n,-)# #(v!z,∈,n)# #(∈,v!x,n,n)# #(∈,v!x,n)# #(v!x,comma,n,nn)# #(v!x,comma,n)# #(comma,v!y,n,nnn)# #(comma,v!y,n)# #(v!y,∩,n,nnnn)# #(v!y,∩,n)# #(∩,v!z,n,nnnnn)# #(∩,v!z,n)# #(v!z,!0,6n)# #(v!z,!0)# #{v!z,6n,-}# #{v!z,6n}# #(end)# is a singleton. title: When did we move from #(start)# #(v!ℤ,m!lsqbrsqb1x1,n,-)# #(v!ℤ,m!lsqbrsqb1x1,n)# #(m!lsqbrsqb1x1,r!,w,n)# #(m!lsqbrsqb1x1,r!,w)# #(r!,v!d,w,nw)# #(r!,v!d,w)# #(v!d,!0,nww)# #(v!d,!0)# #(end)# to the ring of integers #(start)# #(v!𝒪,v!ℚ,b,-)# #(v!𝒪,v!ℚ,b)# #(v!ℚ,m!lsqbrsqb1x1,n,b)# #(v!ℚ,m!lsqbrsqb1x1,n)# #(m!lsqbrsqb1x1,r!,w,bn)# #(m!lsqbrsqb1x1,r!,w)# #(r!,v!d,w,bnw)# #(r!,v!d,w)# #(v!d,!0,bnww)# #(v!d,!0)# #(end)# and why?
body: Gauss made great progress in number theory in #(start)# #(v!ℤ,!0,-)# #(v!ℤ,!0)# #(end)# by working in #(start)# #(v!ℤ,m!lsqbrsqb1x1,n,-)# #(v!ℤ,m!lsqbrsqb1x1,n)# #(m!lsqbrsqb1x1,v!i,w,n)# #(m!lsqbrsqb1x1,v!i,w)# #(v!i,!0,nw)# #(v!i,!0)# #(end)# (or equivalently #(start)# #(v!ℤ,m!lsqbrsqb1x1,n,-)# #(v!ℤ,m!lsqbrsqb1x1,n)# #(m!lsqbrsqb1x1,r!,w,n)# #(m!lsqbrsqb1x1,r!,w)# #(r!,n!-1,w,nw)# #(r!,n!-1,w)# #(n!-1,!0,nww)# #(n!-1,!0)# #(end)#), so much so that we call #(start)# #(v!ℤ,m!lsqbrsqb1x1,n,-)# #(v!ℤ,m!lsqbrsqb1x1,n)# #(m!lsqbrsqb1x1,v!i,w,n)# #(m!lsqbrsqb1x1,v!i,w)# #(v!i,!0,nw)# #(v!i,!0)# #(end)# the Gaussian integers now. And it was even known to the old mathematicians that solutions to Pell's equation #(start)# #(v!x,[n,a],-)# #(v!x,[n,a])# #(v!x,-,n,-)# #(v!x,-,n)# #(-,v!d,n,n)# #(-,v!d,n)# #(v!d,v!y,n,nn)# #(v!d,v!y,n)# #(v!y,[n,a],nnn)# #(v!y,[n,a])# #(v!y,=,n,nnn)# #(v!y,=,n)# #(=,n!1,n,nnnn)# #(=,n!1,n)# #(n!1,!0,nnnnn)# #(n!1,!0)# #(v!y,n!2,a,nnn)# #(v!y,n!2,a)# #(n!2,!0,nnna)# #(n!2,!0)# #(v!x,n!2,a,-)# #(v!x,n!2,a)# #(n!2,!0,a)# #(n!2,!0)# #{n!2,nnna,a,-}# #{n!2,nnna,a}# #(end)# could be better analysed by working in #(start)# #(v!ℤ,m!lsqbrsqb1x1,n,-)# #(v!ℤ,m!lsqbrsqb1x1,n)# #(m!lsqbrsqb1x1,r!,w,n)# #(m!lsqbrsqb1x1,r!,w)# #(r!,v!d,w,nw)# #(r!,v!d,w)# #(v!d,!0,nww)# #(v!d,!0)# #(end)#. I find this confusing, as if we want to study Pell's equation with #(start)# #(v!d,=,n,-)# #(v!d,=,n)# #(=,n!5,n,n)# #(=,n!5,n)# #(n!5,!0,nn)# #(n!5,!0)# #(end)#, we have that #(start)# #(v!𝒪,[n,b],-)# #(v!𝒪,[n,b])# #(v!𝒪,=,n,-)# #(v!𝒪,=,n)# #(=,v!ℤ,n,n)# #(=,v!ℤ,n)# #(v!ℤ,m!lsqbrsqb1x1,n,nn)# #(v!ℤ,m!lsqbrsqb1x1,n)# #(m!lsqbrsqb1x1,f!,w,nnn)# #(m!lsqbrsqb1x1,f!,w)# #(f!,[o,u],nnnw)# #(f!,[o,u])# #(f!,n!1,o,nnnw)# #(f!,n!1,o)# #(n!1,+,n,nnnwo)# #(n!1,+,n)# #(+,r!,n,3n1w1o1n)# #(+,r!,n)# #(r!,n!5,w,3n1w1o2n)# #(r!,n!5,w)# #(n!5,!0,3n1w1o2n1w)# #(n!5,!0)# #(f!,n!2,u,nnnw)# #(f!,n!2,u)# #(n!2,!0,nnnwu)# #(n!2,!0)# #(v!𝒪,v!ℚ,b,-)# #(v!𝒪,v!ℚ,b)# #(v!ℚ,m!lsqbrsqb1x1,n,b)# #(v!ℚ,m!lsqbrsqb1x1,n)# #(m!lsqbrsqb1x1,r!,w,bn)# #(m!lsqbrsqb1x1,r!,w)# #(r!,n!5,w,bnw)# #(r!,n!5,w)# #(n!5,!0,bnww)# #(n!5,!0)# #{n!5,3n1w1o2n1w,bnww,-}# #{n!5,3n1w1o2n1w,bnww}# #{r!,3n1w1o2n,bnw,-}# #{r!,3n1w1o2n,bnw}# #{m!lsqbrsqb1x1,nnn,bn,-}# #{m!lsqbrsqb1x1,nnn,bn}# #(end)# instead of #(start)# #(v!ℤ,m!lsqbrsqb1x1,n,-)# #(v!ℤ,m!lsqbrsqb1x1,n)# #(m!lsqbrsqb1x1,r!,w,n)# #(m!lsqbrsqb1x1,r!,w)# #(r!,n!5,w,nw)# #(r!,n!5,w)# #(n!5,!0,nww)# #(n!5,!0)# #(end)#, which is not what we need. body: For pedagogical purposes, I am looking for an elementary proof (i.e. without resorting to the maximum principle) that #(start)# #(v!f,[n,b],-)# #(v!f,[n,b])# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n,-)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w],n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w])# #(m!()1x1,:=,n,n)# #(m!()1x1,:=,n)# #(:=,f!,n,nn)# #(:=,f!,n)# #(f!,[o,u],nnn)# #(f!,[o,u])# #(f!,v!z,o,nnn)# #(f!,v!z,o)# #(v!z,-,n,nnno)# #(v!z,-,n)# #(-,v!a,n,nnnon)# #(-,v!a,n)# #(v!a,!0,3n1o2n)# #(v!a,!0)# #(f!,n!1,u,nnn)# #(f!,n!1,u)# #(n!1,-,n,nnnu)# #(n!1,-,n)# #(-,v!a,n,nnnun)# #(-,v!a,n)# #(v!a,[n,o],3n1u2n)# #(v!a,[n,o])# #(v!a,v!z,n,3n1u2n)# #(v!a,v!z,n)# #(v!z,!0,3n1u3n)# #(v!z,!0)# #{v!z,o,unnn,nnn}# #{v!z,o,unnn}# #(v!a,¯,o,3n1u2n)# #(v!a,¯,o)# #(¯,!0,3n1u2n1o)# #(¯,!0)# #{v!a,onn,unn,nnn}# #{v!a,onn,unn}# #{-,on,un,nnn}# #{-,on,un}# #(m!()1x1,v!z,w,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!z,w)# #(v!z,!0,nw)# #(v!z,!0)# #{v!z,nno,w,n}# #{v!z,nno,w}# #{v!z,2n1u3n,w,n}# #{v!z,2n1u3n,w}# #(v!f,v!a,b,-)# #(v!f,v!a,b)# #(v!a,!0,b)# #(v!a,!0)# #{v!a,3n1o2n,b,-}# #{v!a,3n1o2n,b}# #{v!a,3n1u2n,b,-}# #{v!a,3n1u2n,b}# #(end)# maps the unit disk into itself when . The usual argument (at least usual for me) is to look at #(start)# #(v!f,[n,b],-)# #(v!f,[n,b])# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n,-)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!e,w,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!e,w)# #(v!e,v!i,a,nw)# #(v!e,v!i,a)# #(v!i,v!t,n,nwa)# #(v!i,v!t,n)# #(v!t,!0,nwan)# #(v!t,!0)# #(v!f,v!a,b,-)# #(v!f,v!a,b)# #(v!a,!0,b)# #(v!a,!0)# #(end)# and check that #(start)# #(m!||1x1,[n,w],-)# #(m!||1x1,[n,w])# #(m!||1x1,=,n,-)# #(m!||1x1,=,n)# #(=,n!1,n,n)# #(=,n!1,n)# #(n!1,!0,nn)# #(n!1,!0)# #(m!||1x1,v!f,w,-)# #(m!||1x1,v!f,w)# #(v!f,[n,b],w)# #(v!f,[n,b])# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n,w)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!e,w,wn)# #(m!()1x1,v!e,w)# #(v!e,v!i,a,wnw)# #(v!e,v!i,a)# #(v!i,v!t,n,wnwa)# #(v!i,v!t,n)# #(v!t,!0,wnwan)# #(v!t,!0)# #(v!f,v!a,b,w)# #(v!f,v!a,b)# #(v!a,!0,wb)# #(v!a,!0)# #(end)#. Then we are done by the maximum principle and the fact that #(start)# #(v!f,[n,b],-)# #(v!f,[n,b])# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n,-)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w],n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w])# #(m!()1x1,=,n,n)# #(m!()1x1,=,n)# #(=,n!0,n,nn)# #(=,n!0,n)# #(n!0,!0,nnn)# #(n!0,!0)# #(m!()1x1,v!a,w,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!a,w)# #(v!a,!0,nw)# #(v!a,!0)# #(v!f,v!a,b,-)# #(v!f,v!a,b)# #(v!a,!0,b)# #(v!a,!0)# #{v!a,nw,b,-}# #{v!a,nw,b}# #(end)#. However, I cannot help but think that there should be an elementary way to do this, using only basic facts about complex numbers such as the triangle inequality. Unfortunately I am running into circles.

But is this true in general for all Euclidean domains ? And how will we prove that

I suspect that this may have something to do with nomes, which Wikipedia mentions but I cannot get my head around. So, my two questions are:  How do I prove the original equivalence? What am I doing wrong in relation to the Jacobi theta function?

title: Trying to find the #(start)# #(v!δ,!0,-)# #(v!δ,!0)# #(end)# in epsilon-delta continuity proof.
body: I am trying to prove the following function is continuous for all irrationals:  The question assumes #(start)# #(v!m,/,n,-)# #(v!m,/,n)# #(/,v!n,n,n)# #(/,v!n,n)# #(v!n,!0,nn)# #(v!n,!0)# #(end)# is in lowest terms. I have shown that it is discontinuous for all rationals, and now I believe I have to either use the #(start)# #(v!ϵ,-,n,-)# #(v!ϵ,-,n)# #(-,v!δ,n,n)# #(-,v!δ,n)# #(v!δ,!0,nn)# #(v!δ,!0)# #(end)# definition of continuity or sequential continuity to show the function is continuous for when #(start)# #(v!x,!0,-)# #(v!x,!0)# #(end)# is irrational. I split my attempt into two cases: Our value of #(start)# #(v!x,!0,-)# #(v!x,!0)# #(end)# is irrational, then I want:  #(start)# #(v!a,!0,-)# #(v!a,!0)# #(end)# is irrational here. Using that #(start)# #(v!x,!0,-)# #(v!x,!0)# #(end)# is irrational I get that #(start)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n,-)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w],n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w])# #(m!()1x1,=,n,n)# #(m!()1x1,=,n)# #(=,n!0,n,nn)# #(=,n!0,n)# #(n!0,!0,nnn)# #(n!0,!0)# #(m!()1x1,v!x,w,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!x,w)# #(v!x,!0,nw)# #(v!x,!0)# #(end)# as does #(start)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n,-)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!a,w,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!a,w)# #(v!a,!0,nw)# #(v!a,!0)# #(end)# so no matter the #(start)# #(v!δ,!0,-)# #(v!δ,!0)# #(end)# we have our condition for continuity  satisfied as  for all #(start)# #(v!δ,!0,-)# #(v!δ,!0)# #(end)# Our value of #(start)# #(v!x,!0,-)# #(v!x,!0)# #(end)# is rational i.e. #(start)# #(v!x,=,n,-)# #(v!x,=,n)# #(=,f!,n,n)# #(=,f!,n)# #(f!,[o,u],nn)# #(f!,[o,u])# #(f!,v!m,o,nn)# #(f!,v!m,o)# #(v!m,!0,nno)# #(v!m,!0)# #(f!,v!n,u,nn)# #(f!,v!n,u)# #(v!n,!0,nnu)# #(v!n,!0)# #(end)# subbing in we want:  I am struggling to find the #(start)# #(v!δ,!0,-)# #(v!δ,!0)# #(end)# necessary. I am able to bound #(start)# #(m!||1x1,f!,w,-)# #(m!||1x1,f!,w)# #(f!,[n,o,u],w)# #(f!,[n,o,u])# #(f!,-,n,w)# #(f!,-,n)# #(-,v!a,n,wn)# #(-,v!a,n)# #(v!a,!0,wnn)# #(v!a,!0)# #(f!,v!m,o,w)# #(f!,v!m,o)# #(v!m,!0,wo)# #(v!m,!0)# #(f!,v!n,u,w)# #(f!,v!n,u)# #(v!n,!0,wu)# #(v!n,!0)# #(end)# by #(start)# #(n!1,+,n,-)# #(n!1,+,n)# #(+,n!2,n,n)# #(+,n!2,n)# #(n!2,m!||1x1,n,nn)# #(n!2,m!||1x1,n)# #(m!||1x1,v!a,w,nnn)# #(m!||1x1,v!a,w)# #(v!a,!0,nnnw)# #(v!a,!0)# #(end)# if I say that #(start)# #(v!δ,≤,n,-)# #(v!δ,≤,n)# #(≤,n!1,n,n)# #(≤,n!1,n)# #(n!1,!0,nn)# #(n!1,!0)# #(end)#. However I do not know how to find a #(start)# #(v!δ,!0,-)# #(v!δ,!0)# #(end)# to yield the second inequality. Should I change my approach to sequential continuity?

body: #(start)# #(v!f,:,n,-)# #(v!f,:,n)# #(:,v!v,n,n)# #(:,v!v,n)# #(v!v,→,n,nn)# #(v!v,→,n)# #(→,v!w,n,nnn)# #(→,v!w,n)# #(v!w,!0,nnnn)# #(v!w,!0)# #(end)# over #(start)# #(v!k,!0,-)# #(v!k,!0)# #(end)# with #(start)# #(v!a,comma,n,-)# #(v!a,comma,n)# #(comma,v!b,n,n)# #(comma,v!b,n)# #(v!b,∈,n,nn)# #(v!b,∈,n)# #(∈,v!v,n,nnn)# #(∈,v!v,n)# #(v!v,!0,nnnn)# #(v!v,!0)# #(end)# and #(start)# #(v!k,∈,n,-)# #(v!k,∈,n)# #(∈,v!k,n,n)# #(∈,v!k,n)# #(v!k,!0,nn)# #(v!k,!0)# #(end)#. Additivity: #(start)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n,-)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w],n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w])# #(m!()1x1,=,n,n)# #(m!()1x1,=,n)# #(=,v!f,n,nn)# #(=,v!f,n)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n,nnn)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w],nnnn)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w])# #(m!()1x1,+,n,nnnn)# #(m!()1x1,+,n)# #(+,v!f,n,nnnnn)# #(+,v!f,n)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n,6n)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!b,w,7n)# #(m!()1x1,v!b,w)# #(v!b,!0,7n1w)# #(v!b,!0)# #(m!()1x1,v!a,w,nnnn)# #(m!()1x1,v!a,w)# #(v!a,!0,nnnnw)# #(v!a,!0)# #{m!()1x1,nnn,nnnn}# #{m!()1x1,nnn}# #{v!f,nnn,nnn}# #{v!f,nnn}# #(m!()1x1,v!a,w,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!a,w)# #(v!a,+,n,nw)# #(v!a,+,n)# #(+,v!b,n,nwn)# #(+,v!b,n)# #(v!b,!0,nwnn)# #(v!b,!0)# #{v!b,6n1w,wnn,n}# #{v!b,6n1w,wnn}# #{+,nnnn,wn,n}# #{+,nnnn,wn}# #{v!a,nnnw,w,n}# #{v!a,nnnw,w}# #{m!()1x1,6n,n}# #{m!()1x1,6n}# #{m!()1x1,nnn,n}# #{m!()1x1,nnn}# #{v!f,6n,-}# #{v!f,6n}# #{v!f,nnn,-}# #{v!f,nnn}# #(end)# Homogenity: #(start)# #(v!k,/*,n,-)# #(v!k,/*,n)# #(/*,v!f,n,n)# #(/*,v!f,n)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n,nn)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w],nnn)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w])# #(m!()1x1,=,n,nnn)# #(m!()1x1,=,n)# #(=,v!f,n,nnnn)# #(=,v!f,n)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n,nnnnn)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!k,w,6n)# #(m!()1x1,v!k,w)# #(v!k,/*,n,6n1w)# #(v!k,/*,n)# #(/*,v!b,n,6n1w1n)# #(/*,v!b,n)# #(v!b,!0,6n1w2n)# #(v!b,!0)# #(m!()1x1,v!b,w,nnn)# #(m!()1x1,v!b,w)# #(v!b,!0,nnnw)# #(v!b,!0)# #{v!b,3n1w2n,w,nnn}# #{v!b,3n1w2n,w}# #{m!()1x1,nnn,nnn}# #{m!()1x1,nnn}# #{v!f,nnn,nn}# #{v!f,nnn}# #{/*,5n1w1n,n}# #{/*,5n1w1n}# #{v!k,6n1w,-}# #{v!k,6n1w}# #(end)# I have a visual understanding that a function is linear if the structure is kept while projecting it with #(start)# #(v!f,!0,-)# #(v!f,!0)# #(end)# but why it is not enough to check if the function is additive? I would be glad to have some easy examples and an intuition why we would have to check both conditions.

title: If the limit does not converge, can the sum? Or, how could the sum converge?
body: Alright, I thought I had seen everything but last night I saw this identity (`twas attributed to Ramanujan), #(start)# #(n!1,+,n,-)# #(n!1,+,n)# #(+,n!2,n,n)# #(+,n!2,n)# #(n!2,+,n,nn)# #(n!2,+,n)# #(+,n!3,n,nnn)# #(+,n!3,n)# #(n!3,+,n,nnnn)# #(n!3,+,n)# #(+,n!4,n,nnnnn)# #(+,n!4,n)# #(n!4,+,n,6n)# #(n!4,+,n)# #(+,v!⋯,n,7n)# #(+,v!⋯,n)# #(v!⋯,=,n,8n)# #(v!⋯,=,n)# #(=,-,n,9n)# #(=,-,n)# #(-,f!,n,10n)# #(-,f!,n)# #(f!,[o,u],11n)# #(f!,[o,u])# #(f!,n!1,o,11n)# #(f!,n!1,o)# #(n!1,!0,11n1o)# #(n!1,!0)# #(f!,n!12,u,11n)# #(f!,n!12,u)# #(n!12,!0,11n1u)# #(n!12,!0)# #{+,nn,nnnnn}# #{+,nn}# #{+,nnnn,nnn}# #{+,nnnn}# #{+,nn,nnn}# #{+,nn}# #{+,6n,n}# #{+,6n}# #{+,nnnn,n}# #{+,nnnn}# #{+,nn,n}# #{+,nn}# #{n!1,11n1o,-}# #{n!1,11n1o}# #(end)# Then I saw a proof that was seemingly correct. So alright, I believe it, hey it is no crazier than having infinities of different sizes and I finally have some closure with that fact. But then, I recalled the benchmark induction proof everyone learns, #(start)# #(∑,[n,o,u],-)# #(∑,[n,o,u])# #(∑,v!i,n,-)# #(∑,v!i,n)# #(v!i,=,n,n)# #(v!i,=,n)# #(=,f!,n,nn)# #(=,f!,n)# #(f!,[o,u],nnn)# #(f!,[o,u])# #(f!,v!n,o,nnn)# #(f!,v!n,o)# #(v!n,m!()1x1,n,nnno)# #(v!n,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!n,w,nnnon)# #(m!()1x1,v!n,w)# #(v!n,+,n,3n1o1n1w)# #(v!n,+,n)# #(+,n!1,n,3n1o1n1w1n)# #(+,n!1,n)# #(n!1,!0,3n1o1n1w2n)# #(n!1,!0)# #{v!n,nw,nnno}# #{v!n,nw}# #(f!,n!2,u,nnn)# #(f!,n!2,u)# #(n!2,!0,nnnu)# #(n!2,!0)# #(∑,v!n,o,-)# #(∑,v!n,o)# #(v!n,!0,o)# #(v!n,!0)# #{v!n,3n1o1n1w,o,-}# #{v!n,3n1o1n1w,o}# #{v!n,nnno,o,-}# #{v!n,nnno,o}# #(∑,v!i,u,-)# #(∑,v!i,u)# #(v!i,=,n,u)# #(v!i,=,n)# #(=,n!1,n,un)# #(=,n!1,n)# #(n!1,!0,unn)# #(n!1,!0)# #{n!1,3n1o1n1w2n,unn,-}# #{n!1,3n1o1n1w2n,unn}# #{=,nn,un,-}# #{=,nn,un}# #{v!i,n,u,-}# #{v!i,n,u}# #(end)# Then kicks in the remains of all those calculus courses I once took, making me thing that, hey wait! We have this, #(start)# #(lim,[n,u],-)# #(lim,[n,u])# #(lim,f!,n,-)# #(lim,f!,n)# #(f!,[n,o,u],n)# #(f!,[n,o,u])# #(f!,=,n,n)# #(f!,=,n)# #(=,v!∞,n,nn)# #(=,v!∞,n)# #(v!∞,!0,nnn)# #(v!∞,!0)# #(f!,v!n,o,n)# #(f!,v!n,o)# #(v!n,m!()1x1,n,no)# #(v!n,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!n,w,non)# #(m!()1x1,v!n,w)# #(v!n,+,n,nonw)# #(v!n,+,n)# #(+,n!1,n,nonwn)# #(+,n!1,n)# #(n!1,!0,1n1o1n1w2n)# #(n!1,!0)# #{v!n,nw,no}# #{v!n,nw}# #(f!,n!2,u,n)# #(f!,n!2,u)# #(n!2,!0,nu)# #(n!2,!0)# #(lim,v!n,u,-)# #(lim,v!n,u)# #(v!n,→,n,u)# #(v!n,→,n)# #(→,v!∞,n,un)# #(→,v!∞,n)# #(v!∞,!0,unn)# #(v!∞,!0)# #{v!∞,nnn,unn,-}# #{v!∞,nnn,unn}# #{v!n,nonw,u,-}# #{v!n,nonw,u}# #{v!n,no,u,-}# #{v!n,no,u}# #(end)# I think in this case we said the limit does not exist or the function diverges (correct me if I am wrong!) But... but... according to the identity above, #(start)# #(∑,[n,o,u],-)# #(∑,[n,o,u])# #(∑,v!i,n,-)# #(∑,v!i,n)# #(v!i,=,n,n)# #(v!i,=,n)# #(=,-,n,nn)# #(=,-,n)# #(-,f!,n,nnn)# #(-,f!,n)# #(f!,[o,u],nnnn)# #(f!,[o,u])# #(f!,n!1,o,nnnn)# #(f!,n!1,o)# #(n!1,!0,nnnno)# #(n!1,!0)# #(f!,n!12,u,nnnn)# #(f!,n!12,u)# #(n!12,!0,nnnnu)# #(n!12,!0)# #(∑,v!n,o,-)# #(∑,v!n,o)# #(v!n,=,n,o)# #(v!n,=,n)# #(=,v!∞,n,on)# #(=,v!∞,n)# #(v!∞,!0,onn)# #(v!∞,!0)# #{=,nn,on,-}# #{=,nn,on}# #(∑,v!i,u,-)# #(∑,v!i,u)# #(v!i,=,n,u)# #(v!i,=,n)# #(=,n!1,n,un)# #(=,n!1,n)# #(n!1,!0,unn)# #(n!1,!0)# #{n!1,nnnno,unn,-}# #{n!1,nnnno,unn}# #{=,nn,un,-}# #{=,nn,un}# #{=,on,un,-}# #{=,on,un}# #{v!i,n,u,-}# #{v!i,n,u}# #(end)# But then shouldn't, #(start)# #(lim,[n,u],-)# #(lim,[n,u])# #(lim,f!,n,-)# #(lim,f!,n)# #(f!,[n,o,u],n)# #(f!,[n,o,u])# #(f!,=,n,n)# #(f!,=,n)# #(=,[n,o],nn)# #(=,[n,o])# #(=,-,n,nn)# #(=,-,n)# #(-,f!,n,nnn)# #(-,f!,n)# #(f!,[o,u],nnnn)# #(f!,[o,u])# #(f!,n!1,o,nnnn)# #(f!,n!1,o)# #(n!1,!0,nnnno)# #(n!1,!0)# #(f!,n!12,u,nnnn)# #(f!,n!12,u)# #(n!12,!0,nnnnu)# #(n!12,!0)# #(=,v!qvar_,o,nn)# #(=,v!qvar_,o)# #(v!qvar_,!0,nno)# #(v!qvar_,!0)# #(f!,v!n,o,n)# #(f!,v!n,o)# #(v!n,m!()1x1,n,no)# #(v!n,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,v!n,w,non)# #(m!()1x1,v!n,w)# #(v!n,+,n,nonw)# #(v!n,+,n)# #(+,n!1,n,nonwn)# #(+,n!1,n)# #(n!1,!0,1n1o1n1w2n)# #(n!1,!0)# #{n!1,nnno,onwnn,n}# #{n!1,nnno,onwnn}# #{v!n,nw,no}# #{v!n,nw}# #(f!,n!2,u,n)# #(f!,n!2,u)# #(n!2,!0,nu)# #(n!2,!0)# #{f!,nnn,n}# #{f!,nnn}# #(lim,v!n,u,-)# #(lim,v!n,u)# #(v!n,→,n,u)# #(v!n,→,n)# #(→,v!∞,n,un)# #(→,v!∞,n)# #(v!∞,!0,unn)# #(v!∞,!0)# #{v!n,nonw,u,-}# #{v!n,nonw,u}# #{v!n,no,u,-}# #{v!n,no,u}# #(end)# So what I am seeing here is that even if the limit does not converge, the sum does. Also, a long time ago I remember being told that the sum of two positive integers is always positive. Furthermore, addition is suppose to be closed under integers right? Here we not only have a negative number as a result of the sum of positive integers but a negative non-integer at that.

That is, if #(start)# #(lim,[n,u],-)# #(lim,[n,u])# #(lim,v!f,n,-)# #(lim,v!f,n)# #(v!f,[n,a],n)# #(v!f,[n,a])# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n,n)# #(v!f,m!()1x1,n)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w],nn)# #(m!()1x1,[n,w])# continuous a jump-discontinuity isn't possible so it appears the slope at the point should be #(start)# #(v!l,!0,-)# #(v!l,!0)# #(end)# too. However, I cannot seem to locate such a theorem, so I suspect my intuition is wrong. Is it?

title: Disjoint axis-aligned rectangles in the plane

Prove that #(start)# #(v!a,!0,-)# #(v!a,!0)# #(end)# is a countable set. title: What is the probability hat two particular players verse in Wimbledon if it begins with #(start)# #(n!16,!0,-)# #(n!16,!0)# #(end)# players?
body: Sixteen people play in the quarter-finals at Wimbledon. The winner of the quarter-finals play again in the semi-final to decide who enters the finals. What is the probability that two particular people will play each other if the tournament begins with 16 players? So I have so far (case 1 + case 2) = verse player in quarter OR verse player in semi = #(start)# #(f!,[n,o,u],-)# #(f!,[n,o,u])# #(f!,+,n,-)# #(f!,+,n)# #(+,f!,n,n)# #(+,f!,n)# #(f!,[n,o,u],nn)# #(f!,[n,o,u])# #(f!,v!…,n,nn)# #(f!,v!…,n)# #(v!…,!0,nnn)# #(v!…,!0)# #(f!,n!14,o,nn)# #(f!,n!14,o)# #(n!14,!0,nno)# #(n!14,!0)# #(f!,n!15,u,nn)# #(f!,n!15,u)# #(n!15,!0,nnu)# #(n!15,!0)# #(f!,n!1,o,-)# #(f!,n!1,o)# #(n!1,!0,o)# #(n!1,!0)# #(f!,n!15,u,-)# #(f!,n!15,u)# #(n!15,!0,u)# #(n!15,!0)# #{n!15,nnu,u,-}# #{n!15,nnu,u}# #{f!,nn,-}# #{f!,nn}# #(end)# I'm not sure what else to include in the second case Also the third part of the question asks What is the probability when #(start)# #(n!2,v!n,a,-)# #(n!2,v!n,a)# #(v!n,!0,a)# #(v!n,!0)# #(end)# players begin? The worked solutions show #(start)# #(f!,[n,o,u],-)# #(f!,[n,o,u])# #(f!,+,n,-)# #(f!,+,n)# #(+,f!,n,n)# #(+,f!,n)# #(f!,[n,o,u],nn)# #(f!,[n,o,u])# #(f!,m!()1x1,n,nn)# #(f!,m!()1x1,n)#
